Hardy-Littlewood maximal inequality

For an f ⁣:R→R\func{f}{\R}{\R}f:R→R belonging to L1(R)L^1\p{\R}L1(R), we define the Hardy-Littlewood maximal function as follows:

(Mf)(x)≔sup⁡h>0 12h∫x−hx+h∣f(y)∣ dy.\p{Mf}\p{x} \coloneqq \sup_{h>0}\,\frac{1}{2h} \int_{x-h}^{x+h} \abs{f\p{y}} \,\diff{y}.(Mf)(x):=h>0sup​2h1​∫x−hx+h​∣f(y)∣dy.

Prove that it has the following property: There is a constant AAA such that for any λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0,

∣{x∈R | (Mf)(x)>λ}∣≤Aλ∥f∥L1\abs{\set{x \in \R \st \p{Mf}\p{x} > \lambda}} \leq \frac{A}{\lambda} \norm{f}_{L^1}∣{x∈R∣(Mf)(x)>λ}∣≤λA​∥f∥L1​

where ∣E∣\abs{E}∣E∣ denotes the Lebesgue measure of EEE. If you use a covering lemma, you should prove it.
Solution.

We will first prove the following covering lemma: let C={B(xα,rα)}α∈I\mathcal{C} = \set{B\p{x_\alpha, r_\alpha}}_{\alpha \in I}C={B(xα​,rα​)}α∈I​ be a collection of open balls in R\RR with {rα}α\set{r_\alpha}_\alpha{rα​}α​ bounded, where III is some indexing set. Then there exists a pairwise disjoint subcollection D⊆C\mathcal{D} \subseteq \mathcal{C}D⊆C such that for any B(xα,rα)∈CB\p{x_\alpha, r_\alpha} \in \mathcal{C}B(xα​,rα​)∈C, there exists B(xβ,rβ)∈DB\p{x_\beta, r_\beta} \in \mathcal{D}B(xβ​,rβ​)∈D such that

B(xα,rα)⊆5B(xβ,rβ)≔B(xβ,5rβ).B\p{x_\alpha, r_\alpha} \subseteq 5B\p{x_\beta, r_\beta} \coloneqq B\p{x_\beta, 5r_\beta}.B(xα​,rα​)⊆5B(xβ​,rβ​):=B(xβ​,5rβ​).

To prove it, let R=sup⁡α∈IrαR = \sup_{\alpha \in I} r_\alphaR=supα∈I​rα​, which is finite by assumption. Partition C\mathcal{C}C into {Cn}n\set{\mathcal{C}_n}_n{Cn​}n​, where Cn\mathcal{C}_nCn​ contains all balls B(xα,rα)∈CB\p{x_\alpha, r_\alpha} \in \mathcal{C}B(xα​,rα​)∈C with radius rα∈(R2n+1,R2n]r_\alpha \in \poc{\frac{R}{2^{n+1}}, \frac{R}{2^n}}rα​∈(2n+1R​,2nR​].

We pick Dn\mathcal{D}_nDn​ as follows: let U0=C0\mathcal{U}_0 = \mathcal{C}_0U0​=C0​, and let D0\mathcal{D}_0D0​ be a maximal disjoint subcollection of U0\mathcal{U}_0U0​, which exists by, say, Zorn's lemma. Now suppose we have chosen D0,…,Dn\mathcal{D}_0, \ldots, \mathcal{D}_nD0​,…,Dn​ along with U0,…,Un\mathcal{U}_0, \ldots, \mathcal{U}_nU0​,…,Un​. Let

Un+1={B∈Cn+1∣B∩C=∅ for all C∈D0∪⋯∪Dn},\mathcal{U}_{n+1} = \set{B \in \mathcal{C}_{n+1} \mid B \cap C = \emptyset \text{ for all } C \in \mathcal{D}_0 \cup \cdots \cup \mathcal{D}_n},Un+1​={B∈Cn+1​∣B∩C=∅ for all C∈D0​∪⋯∪Dn​},

and let Dn+1\mathcal{D}_{n+1}Dn+1​ be a maximal disjoint subcollection of Un+1\mathcal{U}_{n+1}Un+1​. Set D=⋃n=0∞Dn\mathcal{D} = \bigcup_{n=0}^\infty \mathcal{D}_nD=⋃n=0∞​Dn​. We claim that this has the desired properties.

Let B≠C∈DB \neq C \in \mathcal{D}B=C∈D. Then there exist nBn_BnB​ and nCn_CnC​ such that B∈DnBB \in \mathcal{D}_{n_B}B∈DnB​​ and C∈DnCC \in \mathcal{D}_{n_C}C∈DnC​​. If n0≔nB=nCn_0 \coloneqq n_B = n_Cn0​:=nB​=nC​, then by construction, B∩C=∅B \cap C = \emptysetB∩C=∅ since Dn0\mathcal{D}_{n_0}Dn0​​ was chosen to be a disjoint subcollection of Un0\mathcal{U}_{n_0}Un0​​. Otherwise, suppose without loss of generality that nB<nCn_B < n_CnB​<nC​. By construction, C∈UnCC \in \mathcal{U}_{n_C}C∈UnC​​ which was chosen to be disjoint from any ball in D1∪⋯∪DnC−1⊇DnB∋B\mathcal{D}_1 \cup \cdots \cup \mathcal{D}_{n_C-1} \supseteq \mathcal{D}_{n_B} \ni BD1​∪⋯∪DnC​−1​⊇DnB​​∋B, so B∩C=∅B \cap C = \emptysetB∩C=∅, so D\mathcal{D}D is a pairwise disjoint subcollection of C\mathcal{C}C.

As for the intersection property, let B=B(xα,rα)∈CB = B\p{x_\alpha, r_\alpha} \in \mathcal{C}B=B(xα​,rα​)∈C, so there exists nnn such that B∈CnB \in \mathcal{C}_nB∈Cn​, since we had a partition. If B∈UnB \in \mathcal{U}_nB∈Un​, then BBB intersects a ball C∈DnC \in \mathcal{D}_nC∈Dn​, since Dn\mathcal{D}_nDn​ was a maximal disjoint subcollection of Un\mathcal{U}_nUn​. Otherwise, by definition of Un\mathcal{U}_nUn​, there exists C∈D0∪⋯∪Dn−1C \in \mathcal{D}_0 \cup \cdots \cup \mathcal{D}_{n-1}C∈D0​∪⋯∪Dn−1​ such that B∩C=∅B \cap C = \emptysetB∩C=∅. In either case, BBB intersects some ball B(xβ,rβ)∈D0∪⋯∪DnB\p{x_\beta, r_\beta} \in \mathcal{D}_0 \cup \cdots \cup \mathcal{D}_nB(xβ​,rβ​)∈D0​∪⋯∪Dn​, so there exists y∈B(xα,rα)∩B(xβ,rβ)y \in B\p{x_\alpha, r_\alpha} \cap B\p{x_\beta, r_\beta}y∈B(xα​,rα​)∩B(xβ​,rβ​). By construction, rβ>R2n+1r_\beta > \frac{R}{2^{n+1}}rβ​>2n+1R​ and rα≤R2nr_\alpha \leq \frac{R}{2^n}rα​≤2nR​, so 2rβ≥rα2r_\beta \geq r_\alpha2rβ​≥rα​. For any x∈B(xα,rα)x \in B\p{x_\alpha, r_\alpha}x∈B(xα​,rα​), the triangle inequality gives

∣x−xβ∣≤∣x−xα∣+∣xα−y∣+∣y−xβ∣<rα+rα+rβ≤5rβ.\abs{x - x_\beta} \leq \abs{x - x_\alpha} + \abs{x_\alpha - y} + \abs{y - x_\beta} < r_\alpha + r_\alpha + r_\beta \leq 5r_\beta.∣x−xβ​∣≤∣x−xα​∣+∣xα​−y∣+∣y−xβ​∣<rα​+rα​+rβ​≤5rβ​.

Thus, B(xα,rα)⊆B(xβ,5rβ)B\p{x_\alpha, r_\alpha} \subseteq B\p{x_\beta, 5r_\beta}B(xα​,rα​)⊆B(xβ​,5rβ​), as desired.

Notice that D\mathcal{D}D is at most countable: by density of Q\QQ, each Bα∈DB_\alpha \in \mathcal{D}Bα​∈D contains some qα∈Qq_\alpha \in \Qqα​∈Q. Since D\mathcal{D}D is a pairwise disjoint collection, it follows that Bα↦qαB_\alpha \mapsto q_\alphaBα​↦qα​ is an injective map, so D\mathcal{D}D injects into Q\QQ, hence countable.

We now prove the Hardy-Littlewood maximal inequality. By definition, for any x∈E≔{(Mf)(x)>λ}x \in E \coloneqq \set{\p{Mf}\p{x} > \lambda}x∈E:={(Mf)(x)>λ}, there exists hx>0h_x > 0hx​>0 such that

λ<12hx∫x−hxx+hx∣f(y)∣ dy≤12hx∥f∥L1  ⟹  m(Ix)≤1λ∫Ix∣f(y)∣ dy,(1)\tag{1} \lambda < \frac{1}{2h_x} \int_{x-h_x}^{x+h_x} \abs{f\p{y}} \,\diff{y} \leq \frac{1}{2h_x} \norm{f}_{L^1} \implies m\p{I_x} \leq \frac{1}{\lambda} \int_{I_x} \abs{f\p{y}} \,\diff{y},λ<2hx​1​∫x−hx​x+hx​​∣f(y)∣dy≤2hx​1​∥f∥L1​⟹m(Ix​)≤λ1​∫Ix​​∣f(y)∣dy,(1)

where Ix=(x−hx,x+hx)I_x = \p{x - h_x, x + h_x}Ix​=(x−hx​,x+hx​) and mmm denotes the Lebesgue measure. By our covering lemma, there exists {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ such that {Ixn}n\set{I_{x_n}}_n{Ixn​​}n​ is a countable disjoint collection of intervals and such that for any x∈Ex \in Ex∈E, there exists xn0x_{n_0}xn0​​ with Ix⊆5Ixn0I_x \subseteq 5I_{x_{n_0}}Ix​⊆5Ixn0​​​, which implies m(Ix)≤5m(Ixn0)m\p{I_x} \leq 5m\p{I_{x_{n_0}}}m(Ix​)≤5m(Ixn0​​​). Thus,

m(E)≤m(⋃x∈EIx)≤m(⋃n=1∞5Ixn)=5m(⋃n=1∞Ixn)=5∑n=1∞m(Ixn)(countable additivity of m)≤5∑n=1∞1λ∫Ixn∣f(y)∣ dy(by (1) above)=5λ∫⋃nIxn∣f(y)∣ dy(the intervals are pairwise disjoint)≤5λ∥f∥L1,\begin{aligned} m\p{E} \leq m\p{\bigcup_{x \in E} I_x} &\leq m\p{\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty 5I_{x_n}} \\ &= 5m\p{\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty I_{x_n}} \\ &= 5\sum_{n=1}^\infty m\p{I_{x_n}} && (\text{countable additivity of } m) \\ &\leq 5\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\lambda} \int_{I_{x_n}} \abs{f\p{y}} \,\diff{y} && (\text{by (1) above}) \\ &= \frac{5}{\lambda} \int_{\bigcup_n I_{x_n}} \abs{f\p{y}} \,\diff{y} && (\text{the intervals are pairwise disjoint}) \\ &\leq \frac{5}{\lambda} \norm{f}_{L^1}, \end{aligned}m(E)≤m(x∈E⋃​Ix​)​≤m(n=1⋃∞​5Ixn​​)=5m(n=1⋃∞​Ixn​​)=5n=1∑∞​m(Ixn​​)≤5n=1∑∞​λ1​∫Ixn​​​∣f(y)∣dy=λ5​∫⋃n​Ixn​​​∣f(y)∣dy≤λ5​∥f∥L1​,​​(countable additivity of m)(by (1) above)(the intervals are pairwise disjoint)​

which completes the proof.
